Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Liquid organic fertilizer produced through anaerobic digestion of organic waste
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to promote a liquid organic fertilizer (LOF) produced through a novel patented technology which uses anaerobic accelerated bio-leaching of green plant material or green plant waste. The synthetic free liquid organic fertilizer is a complex solution that contains macro nutrients, micro nutrient as well as organic matter in soluble form. The benefits of the proposed product include: (1) improvement of soil biological activities by providing the soil with soluble organic matter; (2) feeding the plants with soluble macro and micro nutrients; (3) ease of transportation; (4) ease of storage; (5) easy adjustment of the nutrient content through dilution; (6) easy application through irrigation systems and; (7) environmental benefit of carbon sequestration. Since no synthetic chemical is used for LOF production, it has the potential to be used as an economic alternative for currently used organic fertilizers such as fish emulsion and composts by the rapidly growing organic farming industry.

This I-Corps project enables the extraction of plants macro and micro nutrients and organic matter from the body of green organic waste such as landscape grass clippings. The proposed novel technology consists of two simultaneous processes of anaerobic digestion and accelerated bio-leaching of organic waste to produce liquid organic fertilizer (LOF). Historically, the use of organic waste for production of organic fertilizer has been through composting. Research has shown that the proposed technology will require less time, lower energy consumption and easily available nutrients when compared to composting. In addition, LOF returns the plant organic carbon back to the soil and contributes to carbon sequestration. Previous studies have also shown that the use of LOF could lead to higher yield in vegetables when compared to synthetic fertilizer.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
1-Market survey: Our team spent the first six months of the project interviewing farmers, golf course and green house managers to assess the potential market for liquid organic fertilizers. The market survey showed that the most promising market for liquid organic fertilizer is the organic farming industry. The organic farmers expressed great interest for our fertilizer because most of the current organic fertilizers that are available in the market have what is called “nutrient lag” issue. The nutrient lag means the nutrients are not easily available for plants uptake when they are needed. The most common organic fertilizers that the farmers are currently using are fish emulation, compost or green fertilizer where typically a legume crop is planted and plowed under prior to planting an organic crop. The nutrients in compost are normally tied up and are in insoluble form. It typically takes compost three years before all the nutrients are released. This lag issue causes nutrient deficiency and consequently low yield and low quality of product in organic farming. The other two fertilizers, fish emulsion and green fertilizer are in complex nutrient form and the nutrient release is slow because the fertilizers need to be digested before nutrients are released and this causes a nutrient lag issue and consequently results in low yield and low product quality.

However, the organic farmers identified two issues that needed to be addressed prior to application of the liquid organic fertilizers. These issues were;

  1. The need to increase the nutrient concentration in the liquid organic fertilizer to at least 5%
  2. The need for ability to store the fertilizer in ambient temperature without losing the fertilizer quality

These two issues were addressed by evaporation of the extra liquid through a Solarization process and by chemical precipitation where a solid organic fertilizer was produced. The storability of the liquid organic fertilizer was accomplished by reducing the PH of the liquid to 2.5 through addition of acid.

2. Commercialization

The effort on marketing resulted in forming a joint company with Vaneta Industries in Georgia to produce and market the liquid organic fertilizer in West Africa. The liquid organic fertilizer has a great potential in Africa where the soils have very low Cation Exchange Capacity (CEC) and cannot store sufficient nutrients. The liquid organic fertilizer has the potential to be applied through foliar application. The Vaneta industries is currently in the process of building a processing plant in Nigeria to produce and market the liquid organic fertilizer to farmers.


Last Modified: 07/01/2019
Modified by: Zohrab A Samani
